string-array.name: tea_descriptions
string-array.item: A type of tea that is more oxidized than oolong, green, and white teas. Generally stronger in flavour, it also has more caffeine. Made from Camellia sinensis leaves.
A traditional semi-oxidized Chinese tea, made from the leaves of the Camellia sinensis plant, the same plant used to make green tea and black tea. Known for its health benefits.
Made from Camellia sinensis leaves that have not been oxidized before drying. Most popular type of tea in Japan and in parts of China.
Made from the infusion or decoction of herbs, spices, or other plant material in hot water. Herbal tea do not usually contain caffeine.

Generally young or minimally processed leaves of the Camellia sinensis plant. White tea is not rolled or oxidized, resulting in a flavour characterized as "lighter" than most green or tradidional black teas.
A herbal tea made by infusing peppermint leaves. Due to the high content of essential oils in leaves, mint tea is popular for its curative effects.
A variety of fermented tea produced in Yunnan province, China. The Chinese consider the Pu-erh tea as the true "black" tea. Its tea leaves are fermented several times over a long period of time.
A traditional drink made from the dried leaves of an evergreen holly, very popular in South America. It provides an energy boost similar to coffee, but with less caffeine and more nutrients.

Finely ground powder of specially grown and processed green tea leaves. Because matcha is made from high-quality tea, and the whole leaves are ingested, it’s a more potent source of nutrients than steeped green tea.

string-array.name: tea_brewing_instructions
string-array.item: - use one teaspoon (one tea bag) per 120-150 ml of water\n- brew your tea with 96°C water\n- your tea should be ready in 3-5 minutes
- use one teaspoon (one tea bag) per 120-150 ml of water\n- brew your tea with 85-96°C water\n- your tea should be ready in 3-5 minutes

- use one teaspoon (one tea bag) per 120-150 ml of water
- brew your tea with 80-85°C water
- your tea should be ready in 2-3 minutes
- extend the brewing time to 4 minutes if you want your tea not to be stimulating
- use one teaspoon (one tea bag) per 120-150 ml of water\n- brew your tea with 96°C water\n- your tea should be ready in 3-6 minutes
- use one teaspoon (one tea bag) per 120-150 ml of water\n- brew your tea with 80-85°C water\n- your tea should be ready in 1-3 minutes

- use 7-10 peppermint leaves (one tea bag) per 250 ml of water
- Crush the peppermint if you are using a fresh leaves - it will help to release the flavor and aroma of the herb
- brew your tea with 96°C water
- your tea should be ready in 7-12 minutes if you are using fresh peppermint leaves, or in 3-10 minutes if you are making a tea from a teabag
- use one teaspoon (one tea bag) per 120-150 ml of water\n- brew your tea with 90°C water\n- your tea should be ready in 3-5 minutes

- pour the yerba mate into the cup (1/2 - 3/4 of its volume)
- shake the cup a bit (holding it upside-down) to redistribute the lighter, more powdery leaves to the top
- tilt the gourd until all the mate is leaning against one side wall of the cup, and add a little bit of a cold water
- insert your bombilla into the empty space
- brew your yerba mate with 70-80°C water
- your yerba mate should be ready - be sure to refill it with water as needed
- remember not to jiggle the bombilla and stir the herb - you'll end up clogging the bombilla and allowing herb into the straw!

- use a half to one teaspoon (1-2 matcha bamboo teaspoons) of matcha per 150 ml of water
- add a little bit of 70-85°C water
- whisk vigorously using a teaspoon or a milk frother until the tea is frothy
- fill the rest of a cup with water - your tea is ready!
